title: If my rent and utilities are included in my income, can i still file ch7. Do i include that Means Test?
question: I am an Apartment Manager, my rent and utilities are included in my monthly salary. Once a month it shows this amount on my paystub however i still get an hourly pay rate. The rent/utility amount is not taxed yet shows on my W2.
answers:
You have the amounts counted on your W2. Clearly your employer considers the rent and utilities part of your income. If you are receiving income in the form of rent and utilities this would need to be included as income for the means test. The real question is whether you have enough income for it to be relevant for the means test.

I would join with the other attorneys and recommend you contact a highly qualified bankruptcy attorney to review your situation and determine whether bankruptcy is what you need. Even if you do the second question is what type of bankruptcy you should file. It never hurts to get the opinion of someone who knows what they are talking about. Given your case would be handled in the Sacramento Federal Bankruptcy Court, your best shot would be to meet with someone who regularly files cases there. Check the avvo ratings and yelp as well as the state bar certified specialist list to find the best attorneys.

Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Some offer a free consultation and might run your numbers thru the Means Test. Unless your family income is over $6000/mo, it is unlikely that your utility credit would make any difference.
You need to see a bankruptcy attorney to review your whole situation. Most don't charge for the initial consultation.
I will reposition this question under bankruptcy.
This is a very good question but better asked of bankruptcy attorneys.
